Summaryof Discharge for Health and Safety Legal Duties throughout the Trust 8
Introduction

Mid and South Essex University Hospitals Group (herein after referred to as the ‘Trust') has statutory obligations under the Health and Safety at Work Act (HSWA) to ensure the health and safety of all employees and anyone affected by their work, so far as is reasonably practicable.

Trust activities pose a wide range of risks, through implementation of this policy, Directors, Managers and all staff must ensure that risks to health and safety are reduced as far as is reasonably practicable. The Trust will include and work collectively with all employees to discharge health and safety responsibilities to embed an intrinsically valued positive safety culture throughout.
To comply with the Health and Safety etc Act 1974 Section (3) the policy must include the following three sections, as listed below:
Policy Statement

The Policy Statement of intent is the written declaration by the Chief Executive on behalf of the Trust's Board, as to the Trust's intentions with regard to the health, safety and welfare of Trust employees and others who may be affected by the Trust's operations.
General Responsibilities
This section deals with personal responsibility for health, safety and welfare at
work.
Arrangements

This section deals with the procedures which have been or will be introduced to ensure this policy is implemented appropriately. It includes procedures for the recognition of hazards, investigating accidents and arrangements for dealing with emergencies.

Everyone employed at the Trust has a legal duty to co-operate in matters of health and safety which includes complying with the requirements of this policy. In addition this duty is extended as a pledge by all NHS employees under the NHS constitution. A summary of general safe expectations and duties under health and safety legislation are listed in appendix 1
Health & Safety Policy Statement

Mid and South Essex University NHS Hospitals Group (Trust) strives to provide safe, caring, and excellent healthcare services, achieved via an ethos of collectively working together. We are committed to meeting responsibilities under the Health and Safety at Work  Act   and  all  associated  legislation  to  ensure,  as  far  as  reasonably practicable, the health, safety and welfare of all employees and others who may be affected by our undertakings.

Our Trust safety, strategy and policy operates on the principle of a collectively owned safety management system, to bring about quality improvement programmes aimed at efficiency  and  effectiveness  to  develop  a  consistent  health  and  safety  culture throughout  our  entire  organisation,  to  support  consistent  exemplar  patient  care practices.

Staff at every level of the organisation should consider safety, health, risk, compliance and assurance aspects throughout all work activities. We expect staff to identify risks and  manage  those  risks  proportionately.  Adequate  resources  will  be  provided  to ensure, where reasonably practicable, these responsibilities are effectively discharged.
Signed
January 2020
Clare Panniker Chief Executive

data.text: Purpose

The onus of responsibility for the Trust's integrated Health, Safety and Welfare agenda cannot be made the responsibility of a single individual or be consigned to a specific department to discharge. This policy sets out the accountability and authority arrangements and health and safety risks on which the Trust will improve its health and safety culture.

This policy is set in the context of the Trust's overall strategic intent to provide excellent patient care and services that distinguish the Trust from its competitors, and effectively supports all those whom support this goal.
This policy sets out the Trust's approach to health and safety and the resources that contribute to a learning culture in a just and fair organisation.
Scope
All staff and other persons working on Trust Premises

‘In the event of an infection outbreak, flu pandemic or major incident, the Trust recognises that it may not be possible to adhere to all aspects of this document. In such circumstances, staff should take advice from their manager and all possible action must be taken to maintain ongoing patient and staff safety'
NHS Constitution

The Trust is committed to: Designing and implementing services, policies and measures that meet the diverse needs of its population and workforce, ensuring that no individual or group is disadvantaged.

This Policy supports the NHS Constitution as follows: The Trust aspires to the highest standards of excellence and professionalism  in the provision of high-quality patient care that is safe, effective and focused on patient experience; in the planning and delivery of the clinical and other services it provides; in the people it employs and the education, training and development they receive; in the leadership and management of its organisations; and through its commitment to innovation and to the promotion and conduct of research to improve the current and future health and care of the population.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities
Committees & Groups

9.1.1 Health & Safety Meetings (HSC / HSMG / HSWG at respective sites) will be responsible for satisfying the statutory requirement to convene a Health and Safety Committee as laid down under the Safety Representative and Safety Committee Regulations 1977, and the Health and Safety (Consultation with Employees) Regulations 1996, as amended. Please refer to associated terms of reference for function, duties and membership of HSC / HSMG / HSWG at their respective sites.
9.1.2 Site Governance Forum will:
Receive H&S exception and/or relevant best practice reports for Directorate implementation that cannot be adequately managed via HSC / HSMG / HSWG level.
Duties of Employees

Members of management may be “employees” within the meaning of health and safety legislation. The duties of employees are given in Sections 7 and 8 of the Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974, which are as follows: - “it shall be the duty of every employee while at work to:
“Take reasonable care for the health and safety of himself and of other persons who may be affected by his acts or omissions at work”
Must co-operate with others to fulfil our statutory duties

“As regards any duty or requirement imposed on his employer or any other person by or under any of the relevant statutory provisions, to co-operate with him so far as is necessary to enable that duty or requirement to be performed or complied with”
“No person shall intentionally or recklessly interfere with or misuse anything provided in the interests of health, safety or welfare in pursuance of any of the relevant statutory provisions".
Must report all incidents and near misses to their line manager, in accordance with the Incident Reporting Policy
Must avoid improvisation and any actions which could create an unnecessary risk to their, or others', personal safety.
Staff must ensure they are familiar with their local fire safety management arrangements and relevant sections of the Frire safety Policy and localised hospital appendicised procedures.

Dress appropriately and safely for their particular working environment in line with Trust's Uniform Policy, using the safety equipment and personal protective equipment (PPE) provided for the task being undertaken.
Report defective PPE to line manager for action to action replacement arrangements.

Must follow any instructions, training and guidance given to them when required to use any machinery, equipment, dangerous substance, and transport equipment, means of production or safety device provided to them by the Trust.
Must not undertake any work for which authorisation and or training has not been given.
Must not bring to work any item of equipment (including electrical appliances) or any substance for which authority has not been given.
Must maintain all equipment in good condition and reporting any defects to their supervisor/ line manager as they occur.
Must if identified as DSE user complete a workstation self-assessment
Must attend, training courses arranged to improve the level of awareness of health and safety issues.

Trust charges staff to report any work situation which could be reasonably considered to give rise to a serious and immediate danger to health and safety and of any situation or work instruction which a could be reasonably considered to represent a shortcoming in the Trusts protection arrangements for health and safety.

Support and encourage adaptations to work processes to ease evidence gathering exercises to give assurance against health and safety strategy and/or externally recognised standards i.e. HSG 65 or ISO standards.
Chief Executive Officer /Managing Directors are accountable for all matters of Health and Safety within the Trust and will ensure:
The Board, Directors and Executive Team understands and accepts its responsibilities and accountabilities for the implementation and monitoring of the Health and Safety Policy
The requirements of health and safety legislation are applied throughout the organisation
Matters of Health and Safety are discussed and Monitored at Trust Board
The Trust's Policies and Codes of practice are observed
That appropriate resources are made available to meet these requirements.
There is a ‘named' executive lead for Health, Safety & Wellbeing for the organisation.
The framework which identifies the levels of management responsible for implementing and monitoring health and safety within the Trust is as follows:
9.4.1 Named Executive Director – The Chief Estates and Facilities Director has delegated executive responsibility for health and Safety in particular for:

Informing the Board on all relevant Health and Safety management issues, including alerting the board to the requirements of this policy and any actual or potential breaches of Health and Safety Legislation.
Ensuring through the Quality and performance structure that, relevant persons are consulted with and informed of any changes that may substantially affect their health and safety.

Ensuring that there are effective systems in place for the management of Health and Safety across the Directorate / Divisional structures of the organisation and that this is monitored through the Health and Safety
Committee / Management Group.
9.4.2 Board of Directors

The Board of Directors have responsibility for ensuring that all Board decisions reflect effective Health and Safety risk management. It will provide leadership through written and oral communications, and by its physical actions, and ensuring that Health and Safety risk management is resourced at all levels as required in meeting its duties.
In carrying out these responsibilities, the Directors will be aware of, and keep abreast of, the appropriate health and safety legislation.

9.4.3 Executive Leads / Directors - Have specific responsibility for the management of Health and Safety throughout their Directorate / Divisions. To enable that responsibility to be effectively discharged they must:
Integrate Health and Safety aspects with all business activities/reviews through the management structure;
Ensure that staff safety forms an integral part of their Governance agenda;
Ensure that all employees receive health and safety training commensurate to their field of employment and level of exposure to risks;
Investigate serious accidents and take appropriate steps necessary to reduce future risks;
Identify hazards associated with their areas of work, and in conjunction with specialist advisors, recommend ways of eliminating them;
Know and keep abreast of the appropriate health and safety legislation;
Ensure that there is an allocated named lead/sponsor for Health and Safety within the Directorate / Division;
Ensure that all matters of Health, Safety, Security and Wellbeing are reported to the Health, Safety and Security committee in line with annual reporting requirements.
9.4.4 Named Executive Director – The Chief Estates and Facilities Director has delegated executive responsibility for health and Safety in particular for:

Managers - have a direct responsibility for implementing the Health and Safety Policy of the Trust and to positively reinforce staff health and wellbeing whilst at work. To enable that responsibility to be effectively discharged they must:

Ensure that all staff who they manage know and understand their responsibilities under the Health and Safety Policy, and that they are equipped through information, training and supervision to play their part
Undertaking the appropriate risk assessments as for generic hazards or those identified in other policies such as Manual Handling, Display screen equipment etc.
Know and operate within all legal and Trust requirements applicable to work within their areas of responsibility. This involves the regular checking of these requirements against actual practice.
Promote appropriate health and safety and wellbeing programs.

Ensure that all health and safety operating procedures and instructions are known and observed. Regularly review and examine these procedures and instructions in practice and discuss them with employees concerned with the aim of ensuring that they are still workable and understood.
As part of the normal routine, maintain high standards of housekeeping through auditing of health and safety practices relating to the operation of the department.

Ensure that health and safety receives full consideration in current Trust practices, planning new methods of work, use of new equipment and the commissioning or carrying out of health and safety risk assessments as required by Trust policies.
Ensure that the health and safety training needs of all staff are identified and training is carried out to enable staff to perform their duties correctly.
Ensure no new or transferred employee is required to undertake any task without appropriate instruction, information, training or supervision.
All training should be evaluated for its effectiveness and recorded.

Ensure that after formal assessment for suitability and appropriateness, personal protective clothing and safety equipment is readily available and used at all times, where such clothing and equipment is necessary to safeguard employees safety.
At all times set a good example for employees to follow.

Ensure that all injuries and dangerous occurrences, near misses (however slight), and exposures to hazardous materials are reported in accordance with the Trust's adverse incident reporting procedure, ensuring all necessary investigations and reporting procedures are carried out
Examine all accident reports and implement any remedial actions.

Support and encourage adaptations to work processes to ease evidence gathering exercises to give assurance against health and safety strategy and/or externally recognised standards i.e. HSG 65 or ISO standards.
Ensure that health and safety considerations are incorporated in job descriptions.
Periodically inspect and monitor working practices to ensure compliance with relevant legislation and best current practice.
9.4.5 Health and Safety link workers (where present) Nominated H&S link workers are responsible for ensuring that:
With support from the Directorate / Divisional senior management team that Staff health and safety issues form an integral part of the governance agenda.
A health and safety report is submitted to the associated Trust HSC/HSMG/HSWG in line with scheduled meetings.
They co-ordinate the completion of Health and Safety risk assessments throughout their areas
They act as ‘a link' between the the associated Trust HSC/HSMG/HSWG Directorate / Divisional management teams for reporting and escalating H&S concerns

9.4.6 Head of Health & Safety & Local Health and Safety Managers - Hold delegated responsibility to act the competent person for Health and Safety matters across the organisation advising the Trust in respect of health and safety policy formulation and development. Additionally in carrying out their duties the Health, Safety & Wellbeing Manager will:
Have the authority to order the cessation of ay process or activity which he considers to be unsafe or in breach of the Health and Safety at Work Act or any of the Health and Safety Regulations.
Interpret legislation and guidance in order to develop, and then implement or assist others with the implementation of Trust wide corporate policies and procedures.
Assist in the identification of health and safety training needs and, where appropriate, deliver or arrange to be delivered, such training as may be necessary for the health and safety of employees.
Liaise on behalf of the Trust with external bodies enforcing the HSWA and other relevant health and safety legislation that is in place.
Adopt a standard systems approach to safety management across the Trust.
Ensure that non-compliance notices from external bodies for health, safety and fire are escalated and acted upon accordingly.
Provide advice on specific health and safety issues.
Carry out agreed periodic audits/inspections of work areas
Be a resource available to managers and staff for compliance with the Health and Safety at Work etc. Act and subordinate legislation
Contribute to the production of the Trust's annual Occupational Health and Safety plan.
Monitor staff work related Accidents and Incidents.

Report into the Chief Estates Officer of Estates and Facilities and undertake actions cascaded on their behalf from the Director of Specialist Services Trust Board, and Chief Executive/Managing Directors.
9.4.7 Health & Safety Advisors
Advise the Trust Board through the (Head of and/or) Health & Safety Manager on Health and Safety Issues.
Has the authority to order the cessation of any process or activity which he considers to be unsafe or in breach of the Health and Safety at Work Act or any of the Health and Safety Regulations.
Provide competent and professional advice and assistance with regards to health and safety matters to all levels of staff.
Keep Directors and Managers advised with regard to actual or anticipated changes in health and safety legislation and accepted best practices.

Undertake accident and dangerous occurrence investigations and provide reports to Security, Safety and Fire Manager and, when required by law, the HSE with reports of such incidents and dangerous occurrences to comply with RIDDOR.

In conjunction with the Occupational Health Department undertake investigations into cases of work related ill health and provide management and, where required by law the HSE, with reports on such cases.
Provide support and assistance to those who are required to implement the requirements of the safety policy and any of the safety management procedures.
Liaise with union and staff side appointed safety representatives on matters relating to health and safety through regular monthly meetings.
Receive pre inspection reports and undertake environmental inspections in line with H&S Inspection Policy.
Develop, implement and monitor a planned programme of health and safety inspections.
Encourage a positive safety culture through promotion of all health and safety matters.
Carry out reviews health and safety incidents via the incident reporting system.
Manage the Trusts COSHH database SYPOL and ensure it remains up to date and valid.
9.4.8 Manual Handling (Advisory) Team
Ensure implementation and the monitoring of the Trust Manual Handling Policy
Assess and advise on the ergonomics of the working environment and specific manual handling tasks.
Develop and provide training in safe handling techniques
Advise on areas of risk regarding manual handling operations.
Follow up any accident/incident or near miss report involving manual handling, those which require reporting to the HSE to comply with RIDDOR, to be escalated to the Health and Safety Advisor
Audit the need for manual handling equipment.
Advise on the purchase of manual handling equipment.
9.4.9 Fire Officers
Facilitating the Head of Fire Safety in the discharge of the roles and responsibilities outlined above;
Providing competent expert advice on the application and interpretation of fire legislation and fire safety guidance;
Advising the Head of Fire Safety on the means of fulfilling existing, and forthcoming statutory obligations related to healthcare premises;
Advising on and keeping under review the content of this fire safety policy and procedure;

Providing assurance to the Head of Fire Safety and Nominated Fire Safety Director, annually, via audit and report that the management policies regarding fire safety, comply with the provisions of the Order and as far as reasonably practicable all relevant guidance;

Performing a Trust - wide planned programme of regular inspections and fire risk assessments to ensure compliance with all statutory fire safety legislation; ensure compliance against the British Standards for all fire safety related equipment. These standards to be checked at the time of inspection and any deficiencies reported and acted upon.
Ensure compliance against the British Standards for all fire safety related equipment. These standards to be checked at the time of issue and any deficiencies reported and acted upon.
Assisting with the development, review and implementation of this policy and procedure and underpinning documents;
Delivery of training;
As required liaising with enforcing authorities on technical issues;
As required liaising with managers and staff on technical fire safety issues
As required liaising with any contracted competent persons or Authorising Engineer (Fire);
As required reporting of all fire incidents in accordance with reporting requirements;
Investigating all fire related incidents and providing an investigation report to the Head of Health, Safety & Risk within 25 days of the incident,
Providing monthly standing fire safety reports at each the Health and Safety Committee;
Advising on construction new build and refurbishment fire safety plans;
Preparing reports including standing reports as required;
Monitoring through audit fire precaution arrangements on Trust premises to ensure compliance with the order.
Supporting assurance processes through monitoring and reporting as required.
9.4.10 Local Security Management Specialist
To assist the Trust in carrying out its security responsibilities.
To advise the Chief Executive, the Security Management Director and all other managers on security, and act as an advisor of various committees.
To assist and give advice for other staff to carry out security risk assessments.
To investigate all cases of theft and any other security related incidents.

9.4.11 Other Trust Specialist Advisors (Competent Persons) These advisors are responsible for areas to which they are qualified or have competency to do so. The Trust currently supports the following advisors:
Radiological Protection Advisor;
Infection Prevention and Control;
Risk Management.
9.4.12 Staff Side Representatives Staff members shall consist of accredited representatives from the following Unions or be nominated department safety representatives:

AMICUS, UNISON, British Dental Association, British Dietetic association, British and Irish Orthoptic Society, British Medical Association, Community and District Nursing Association, Chartered Society of Physiotherapy, Royal College of Midwives, Royal College of Nursing, Society of Chiropodists and Podiatrists, Society of Radiographers,
Transport and General Workers Union, Unison, Union of Construction, Allied Trades and Technicians, or
as shall be determined from time to time by the Committee.
9.4.13 Health and Safety Representatives The Trust must consult with employee Health and Safety Representatives
with a view to making and maintaining arrangements which enable
employers and employees to co-operate effectively in promoting and
developing measures to ensure employees health and safety at work, and in
checking the effectiveness of such measures.

Appointed Health and Safety Representatives may cover one or more work locations in respect of dealing with health and safety brought to their attention by the members. Such matters should be dealt with by representation to management via the agreed communications structure.

Appointed Health and Safety Representatives may take part in the regular inspections with management appointed representatives of all Trust work locations and premises. Additionally, where a substantial change in the conditions of work has taken place e.g. introduction of new machinery/equipment, or new information has been published by the Health and Safety Commission or Executive relevant to the hazards of the workplace, additional inspections may take place following appropriate consultation with management.
9.4.14 Occupational Health Department
To provide health surveillance to particular staff exposed to occupational hazards in accordance with current legislation;
To provide on employment medical screening;
Responsible for health education;
To assist and advise where a risk to health exists;
Provide safety/risk training for managers and link workers;
Provide first aid training and certificate validation.
9.4.15 Collaboartive Operatives / Estates and Facilities Services Operatives and (as per contractual agreement) PFI equivalent operatives

Shall be responsible for maintaining the site in a safe condition including plant and ensuring the effective provision of health, safety and welfare to those staff working for them under Retained Offer of Employment model by secondment arrangements in accordance with in house processes or company guidelines as set out in the service specification. They will be consulted on and in all matters pertaining to health, safety and welfare in respect of joint occupier's liability. They will control of contractors to ensure the provision of effective and safe services to the Trust and to act as the Trust's competent person for the following areas:
Asbestos;
Legionella;
Medical gases (excepting Pharmacy provision)
Permits to work (electricity, hot work, roofs etc)
Decontamination certification for medical devices that they work upon
Food Safety
Waste Management (Environmental and Special Waste Regulations)
9.4.16 Agency & Bank Workers (Temporary Staff)
Line Managers must ensure that all temporary staff are made aware of the existing emergency procedures and the action to be taken should an emergency situation arise.
Localised Health and Safety training should take place and should cover topics relating to the working environment e.g.
a) the work area.
b) work procedures.
c) personal protective equipment (PPE) — types available.
d) health surveillance.
e) site safety rules.
In order for temporary workers to conform to site procedures, site rules must be brought to their attention and in particular any safety rules relating to their department or work area.
Process
In order to effectively manage Health and Safety across the Organisation managers should follow the  Managing for Health and Safety guidance produced by the HSE.
Safety Management Strategy and Systems Thinking Approaches

The Trust health and safety strategy will adopt the “Plan – Do – Check – Act” safety management model (Refer to fig 1) as detailed within Health and Safety Executive – Managing for health and Safety  HSG . This approach additionally forms the management basis of ISO 45001 which MSE Trust may wish to pursue as an intenationally and externally approved standard to evidence the Trust's commitment to health and safety throughout.
PLAN Determine the Trust's plan, objectives, policies and processes
necessary to deliver results in accordance with the H&S policy. DO Identify risks, report incidents and near misses, organise work for
the promotion of a safe and healthy workplace.
CHECK Measure performance, monitor events, investigate incidents, report
result vis health and safety committee/group meetings.
ACT Review performance, learn from incidents, and act on lessons
learnt actions to continually improve the health & safety performance to achieve the intended outcomes.

10.1.1 The Health and Safety Strategy will maintain a proactive local Hospital Health and Safety Committee / Group for robust consultation and discussion with stakeholders.  The  Health  and  Safety  Committee  /  Group  will  report  by exception into local Site Governance Forums.

10.1.2 The Trust will receive an annual report of generic health and safety progress and performance against agreed indicators and a monthly escalation report will go via the site Governance forums and/or in response to specific issues or concerns.
10.1.3 The Trust will maintain competent specialist advice on all matters related to and impacting upon the safety, health and wellbeing of our staff and stakeholders.

10.1.4 The strategy will potentially pave the way to consider Trust wide evaluation of our  process  via  external  review  i.e. This will  be initially  tested  via  British Standards  Institute  evaluation  against  ISO  45001;  The  International Occupational Safety Standard across Estates and Facilities Directorate for the three major MSE hospital sites.
Figure 1: HSG 65: Plan-Do-Check-Act Safety Management Model
10.1.5 Defining approached to evaluate and understand system wide effects.

10.1.5.1  A system thinking approach can help decode complexities within a healthcare establishment and use this understanding to design and evaluate interventions that maximise system performance and patient safety. This involves;
1) Understand and model the system wide implications of interventions,
2) Choose and design intervention,
3) Utilise mixed evaluation methods that address system wide issues.
10.1.6 Systems thinking culture

To realise the benefits, systems thinking must become an integral part of the practices within the healthcare organisation. The result of effective systems thinking culminates in a new capacity for reflective dialogue, deep insight and shifting entrenched mental models. The ultimate objective of a systems- thinking approach is to build a safe environmental in which all stakeholders can discover the hidden consequences of their collective actions and challenge their thinking.

10.1.6.1  By applying a systems thinking (and facilitating this via a common proactive risk management approach via Deming / Risk based models) MSE will operate more successfully and effectively by identifying and resolving healthcare systems challenges.
10.1.7 Health & Safety Management Strategy

The Trust Board are in support of Health & Safety Management strategy this is based upon a system as endorsed and/or recommended by National Health and Safety professional bodies / Health and safety Exeutive.
Assessing Risk

The Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations requires the Trust to undertake regular risk assessments of the workplace. These assessments should identify the risks to employees whilst at work and the risks to non- employees arising from, or in connection with, the Trusts activities.
As well as general risk assessments, the following specific assessments may also need to be undertaken in accordance with relevant rust policies:
Control of Substances hazardous to health (COSHH) assessments
Display Screen Equipment assessments
Manual Handling assessments
Fire Risk assessments
Security assessments
Lone working
Use of conventional sharps assessment
‘Staff' usage of items containing latex assessment
Ligature risk assessments
Violence and Aggression
Stress assessments
New and Expectant Mothers assessment
10.2.1 Risk assessments should be undertaken across all care groups ensuring that the findings of the risk assessments are shared to employees and escalated to risk registers where appropriate.
10.2.2 All risk assessments should be subject to review in the following circumstances:
Whenever there is a significant change e.g. staff, environment or equipment;
Following an accident or near miss;
After non-compliance identified through audit or inspection;
At least annually.
Key Health and Safety Management Arrangements
(Refer to Appendix 1&2 for generic Health and Safety arrangements within the workplace)

10.3.1 All staff should make themselves aware of the Trusts Risk Management Policy, which is available on the intranet. In addition each Directorate / Division may have produced its own Health and Safety local procedures.
10.3.2 All current procedures must be adhered to, if staff are in any doubt to their actions or accountabilities, they should contact their line manager.

10.3.3 Day to day responsibilities are defined in the Risk Management Policy, there will be specific areas of risk in each workplace, for which certain controls will be identified. Staff should make themselves aware of these risks and report any changes immediately to their line manager.
10.3.4 Common citeria for health and safety/safety risk management are listed in Appendix  with summaried mitigation arrangements or reference to a dedicated policy or process.
Workplace Inspection

8.4.1 Inspection of an areas will be undertaken in line with local Trust Health and Safety Inspection policy for clinical, engineering space and public asccess areas. In addition to focussed inspections to support risk assessment, incident management and premises, process or equipment improvement programme proposals.

10.4.2 All relevant operatives (those with assigned actions) will support so far as reasonably practicable the recommendations and actions leading from audit / inspection reports. This will include where necessary adapting work

processes to gain assurance evidence of task completion, which in turn will achieve, implement and maintain both the Trust of Health and safety Strategy and future external desirable recognised standards. i.e. ISO 45001 Health and Safety Standard, ISO 9001 Quality Management Standard, ISO 14001 Environmental Management Standard
Accident and Incident management
10.5.1 In order to monitor trends and prevent reoccurrence it is important that workplace accidents and incidents are appropriately reported using our internal reporting procedures.
10.5.2 All staff are actively encouraged to report incidents, including near misses at their earliest opportunity utilising the Trust incident reporting system.
10.5.3 Mangers must:
Ensure that there are adequate systems in place to review incidents that occur within their areas
Ensure that appropriate post incident support is made available to staff as required

Ensure that the Health and Safety Manager is notified of all incidents that may be deemed as RIDDOR reportable – further information is available in the RIDDOR Guide for managers available on the Trust Intranet.
RIDDOR Reportable Incidents

10.6.1 The Trust must report an event to the Health and Safety Executive if it meets the requirements of the Reporting of Injuries Diseases and Dangerous Occurrence Regulations (RIDDOR 2013). Such as:

'Fatality': All deaths to workers and non-workers must be reported if they arise from a work-related accident, including an act of physical violence to a worker. Suicides are not reportable, as the death does not result from a work-related accident.

'Specified Injuries': If there is an accident connected with work and an employee or a member of the public or self-employed person working on the premises sustains a specified injury, or a member of the public suffers an injury and is taken to hospital from the site of the accident or if they are in hospital suffered from a specified injury
or admittance to hospital for more than 24 hours

'An over-7-day' injury is one which is not "Specified" but results in the injured person being away from work OR unable to do their full range of their normal duties for more than seven consecutive days
'Reportable Diseases': Employers people must report diagnoses of certain occupational diseases, where these are likely to have been caused or made worse by their work.
'Reportable Dangerous Occurrence': Dangerous occurrences are certain, death or serious injury incidents with the potential to cause harm. Not all such events require reporting.
RIDDOR Incidents just reported to the HSE within 15 days of incident/accident occurrence.

10.6.2 All RIDDOR events must be reported by the Trust Health and Safety Manager or Health and Safety Advisor either immediately or upon the th day that an employee has not returned to work following a workplace accident, and logged onto the Trust incident reporting system.

10.6.3 All incidents should be investigated by the appropriate manager with any identified remedial action addressed. All RIDDOR events must be investigated by the Health and Safety Manager, or Health and Safety Advisor
10.6.4 Serious events must be reported immediately and will be managed in accordance with the MSE agreed incident management.
Health Surveillance

10.7.1 In order to monitor the effectiveness of the measures introduced to reduce risks to the health of employees, a programme of health surveillance will be undertaken which will be co-ordinated by the Occupational Health Department
10.7.2 Examples of the circumstances which may be selected for a programme of health surveillance will include exposure to:
respiratory irritants;
use of products likely to cause Asthma or Dermatitis;
excessive noise;
asbestos;
ionising Radiation;
vibration;
substances when COSHH assessment deems surveillance necessary;
stress;
musculoskeletal disorders.
Arrangements for Emergencies and Imminent Danger

10.8.1 In order to ensure the safety of employees, patients, contractors and visitors and members of the public and to comply with the requirements of Regulation 8 of the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations, procedures will be devised which will be implemented in the event of emergency or imminent danger. This will be the responsibility of the Trust's Emergency Planning Officer (EPO). Periodic exercises and table top training will be carried out to ensure the plans that are in place are robust.
10.8.1.1  Please refer to following :
Local Hospital Emergency Planning and Resilience Procedures
Bomb Threats Procedure
Security Policy and associated procedures
10.8.2 Examples of emergency and imminent danger include:
Major Accidents or illness to staff
Gas leaks
Natural disaster flood or water damage
Fire
Bomb threat
Power failure
Act of violence
Theft and vandalism
Spillages of toxic or flammable substances

10.8.4  Each department or work area will have a plan for the purposes of the safe evacuation of persons in the event of emergency or imminent danger. The relevant emergency plans will be held by each department or area of work.
Purchase of Equipment, Materials and Substances

10.9.1 Any item of equipment or any materials or substances which are purchased for use at work should only be purchased through NHS Procurement, in line with the latest procurement strategy and the Trust's local Medical Equipment Management arrangements.
10.9.2 Any such purchases must follow the Trust's risk assessment procedure and where there is thought to be significant risk the assessment must be recorded,
Selection of Contractors

10.10.1 Every employer or self employed person, who expresses an interest in tendering for contracted-out work on behalf of line management at the Trust, will be subjected to an appraisal and selection procedure.
10.10.2 Such procedures will require them to submit the following:
A properly prepared Health and Safety Policy;
A systematic programme of risk assessment;
Safe procedures of work and method statement;
Confirmation of competence and training.
10.10.3 All appointed contractors will adhere to the Trust's Control of Contractors Policy (and collaboarative contractual processes / agreements for PFI managed Trust buildings)
Training Requirements

Health & Safety forms part of the Trust's Core Essential Skills and Training requirements, as identified by the Training Needs Analysis Matrix. Health & Safety is delivered as part of Mandatory Corporate Induction for all staff on commencement of their employment within the trust.
11.2.1  Local Induction for staff

As part of local induction, managers should satisfy themselves that their staff are able to recognise the hazards associated with the workplace and the associated control measures. All local induction will be recorded in accordance with Trust Policy on Local Induction.
11.2.3  Health and safety Awareness (Statutory & Mandatory)

As part of Statutory and mandatory training needs analysis – Health and Safety Awareness training is offered via an e-lerning package to facilitate a general understanding for safety behaviours and risks to maintain safe working practices within the Trust.
Relevant Health and Safety updates will be made available and provided to all staff as required by the following means:
Health and Safety Newsletter
Team brief
Link Articles
Department/locally delivered update training as required
Specialised safety training will be offered via
Health and Safety Team for i.e. Safety link workers, COSHH SYPOL system usage, completion of quarterly/ annual safety inspection audit by manager/safety link worker.

Specific Departments i.e. Radiology for person(s) with associated safe practice practice responsibilities, Esates for Contractor site safety induction. Records of successful completion for this training will held by department organising the training.

The uptake of training is tracked by the use of the Electronic Staff training records system and monitored through the the Directorate/Divisional structure, or elearning system reports to Health and Safety committee/Management Groups.
Raising Awareness
In addition to the training described above there are:
Workshops and events guided and/ or undertaken by the Occupational Health & Safety Team
Displays and information bulletins using the Trust intranet system
Posters displayed in work areas
Participating in the National Awareness Days
Monitoring compliance with procedural documents

Appendix 1 Health and Safety Management Provision at Work
Health and Safety
What you should know
Your health, safety and welfare at work are protected by law.
Your employer has a duty to protect you and keep you informed about health and safety.
You have a responsibility to look after yourself and others.
If there is a problem, discuss it with your employer or safety representative, if there is one.
This leaflet is a brief guide to health and safety law. It does not describe the law in detail, but it does list the key points.
Your employer has a duty under the law to ensure, so far as is reasonably practicable, your health, safety and welfare at work.
The Trust will consult you or your safety representative on matters relating to your health and safety at work, including:
Any change which may substantially affect your health and safety at work, e.g. in procedures, equipment or ways of working;
The employer's arrangements for getting competent people to help him/her satisfy health and safety laws;

The information you have to be given on the likely risks and dangers arising from your work, measures to reduce or get rid of these risks and what you should do if you have to deal with a risk or danger;
the planning of health and safety; and
The health and safety consequences of introducing new technology.
In general, the Trust's duties include:
Making your workplace safe and without risks to health;
Ensuring plant and machinery are safe and that safe systems of work are set and followed;
Ensuring articles and substances are moved, stored and used safely:
Providing adequate welfare facilities;
Giving you the information, instruction, training and supervision necessary for your health and safety.
In particular, The Trust must:
Assess the risks to your health and safety;
Make arrangements for implementing the health and safety measures identified as being necessary by the assessment;
Record the significant findings of the risk assessment and the arrangements for health and safety measures;
Draw up a health and safety policy statement,
Including the health and safety organisation and arrangements in force, and bring it to your attention;
Appoint someone competent to assist with health and safety responsibilities, and consult you or your safety representative about this appointment;
Co-operate on health and safety with other employers sharing the same workplace;
Set up emergency procedures;
Provide adequate first-aid facilities;
Make sure that the workplace satisfies health, safety and welfare requirements, e.g. for ventilation, temperature, lighting, and sanitary, washing and rest facilities;
Make sure that work equipment is suitable for its intended use, so far as health and safety is concerned, and that it is properly maintained and used;
Prevent or adequately control exposure to substances which may damage your health;
Take precautions against danger from flammable or explosive hazards, electrical equipment, noise and radiation;
Avoid hazardous manual handling operations, and where they cannot be avoided, reduce the risk of injury;
Provide health surveillance as appropriate;
Provide free any protective clothing or equipment, where risks are not adequately controlled by other means;
Ensure that appropriate safety signs are provided and maintained;
Report certain injuries, diseases and dangerous occurrences to the appropriate health and safety enforcing authority.
As an employee you have legal duties too. They include:
Taking reasonable care for your own health and safety and that of others who may be affected
by what you do or do not do;
Co-operating with the Trust on health and safety;
Correctly using work items provided by your employer, including personal protective equipment, in accordance with training or instructions; and
Not interfering with or misusing anything provided for your health, safety or welfare.
Report all incidents and episodes of ill health, regardless of the outcome, severity or level/type of harm
(N.B. Above information compliles by Health and Safety Executive)

APPENDIX 2 Health and Safety / Risk Citeria and Summary of Arrangements (Please note list below is not exhaustive and may have dedicated Policy in place for process implementation)
N.B. In addition please refer to Health and Safety Strategy for key safety risks for routine management Control of Substances Hazardous to Health (COSHH)

The COSHH Regulations require Trust to evaluate and control the risks to health for all employees from the exposure to hazardous substances at work. This includes exposure to microbiological agents, dusts and hazardous (to health) chemicals. Cytotoxic drugs are a COSHH regulated substance as there is a duty to protect operatives whom administer these drugs to a patient.
Trust utilises a web based system SYPOL to generate COSHH Assessments for each identified hazardous substance. Trust COSHH arrangements are implemented via HS-19 COSHH Policy for detailed guidance.
Emergency Procedures, Fire and Evacuation

The Trust's Senior Fire Officer will ensure suitable Fire Risk Assessments are carried out, staff must make themselves aware of the arrangements for their work area, identifying escape routes, fire fighting equipment, alarms and evacuation procedures.

Fire equipment is checked every 12 months and all staff are required to attend mandatory fire training. Mandatory training updates are required in accordance with training needs analysis (Learning and Development Strategy).
Accidents, Work Related Ill Health and Near Miss Reporting

All accidents, incidents, dangerous occurrences and near misses must be reported in line with the Trusts Incident Reporting Policy and agreed processes. The DATIX (MEHT / SUH) or ULYSSES (BTUH) incident reporting systems are utilised at MSE sites to report accidents, dangerous occurrences, incident and near misses at time of policy generation.
First Aid (Refer to local Trust First Policy for detailed guidance)

The aim of first aid is to reduce the effects of illness or injury experienced at work caused by the work itself or other factors. The level of first aid provision is determined by an assessment of first aid needs and must be adequate and appropriate to the circumstances. This need not be formal or recorded assessment
The Trust will ensure that there are sufficient first aid personnel or qualified staff and facilities to:
Give immediate assistance
Summon help (ambulance or other professional assistance)
First aid cover is supplied within the Trust as per arrangements within the First aid Policy and HSE Guidance L74

Provided they can demonstrate current knowledge and skills in first aid, the training and experience of the following qualify them to administer first aid in the workplace without the need to hold a First Aid at Work, Emergency First Aid at Work or equivalent qualification:
Doctors registered and licensed with the General Medical Council;
Nurses registered with the Nursing and Midwifery Council;
Paramedics registered with the Health and Care Professions Council

If a first aid needs assessment highlights the need, then a locally nominated first aider or appointed person must be identified within your work area. All staff should make themselves aware of the location of the first aid facility or first aider provisions.
Occupational Health Department will conduct health surveillance and investigate work related incidents of ill health or any issue raised through the risk assessment or ill health referrals process.
Moving and Handling (Refer to local Moving and Handling Policy for detailed guidance)

The Trust has a dedicated Moving, and Handling Advisor is in place to develop and support the manual handling procedures within the Trust. The Trust will ensure current Policy and practice is developed in line with current legislation, the Manual Handling Operations Regulations and the backcare publication;The Guide to the Handling of People (6th edition). Managers should ensure staff attend training updates in accordance with Trust's training needs analysis (Mandatory Training Policy).
All moving and handling tasks should take into account current best practice in line with the Trust's Moving and Handling Policy.

There are various controls and guidance in place on the use of moving and handling equipment and staff must not use this equipment unless they have the appropriate training. It is important line managers are advised if you are pregnant or ill as this may affect your ability to assist in the moving and handling task.
Display Screen Equipment (Refer to Local Display Screen Equipment policy for detailed guidance)

The Display Screen Equipment Regulations (DSE) require employers to assess work stations are safe and comfortable for use. Staff defined as a display screen user will be given advice on the layout and set up of their workstation.
The Trust DSE Policy and employee assessments are available on the intranet and must be used in addressing the risk to staff.
Pregnancy and Work (Refer to the MSEPO-20224 Family Friendly Policy for detailed guidance).

Pregnancy is a natural state, which must not be treated as ill health. All staff should be aware that through risk assessment some changes might need to be made to the controls within the working environment. The MSEPO-20224 Family Friendly Policy contain a risk assessment tool. This can also be found on the Health and Safety pages of the intranet.

A risk assessment form is available on the Intranet to assist line managers and their employees in establishing the controls required for assessing the risk to a pregnant employee or returning mother.
Lone workers (Refer to Lone Working Policy

Where staff may be at risk from working either in isolation or away from the hospital a suitable risk assessment should be undertaken. The assessment should reflect upon the risks to the member of staff and the controls that need to be put in place to provide a safe system of work.
Young Workers
The Trust will undertake its responsibilities towards any young worker (under the age of 18) in accordance with The Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999 (Regulation 19).

Slips, Trips and Falls (refer to The Management of Slips Trips and Falls Policy HS-25 for detailed guidance) The Trust has a duty under the Health and Safety at Work Act  Section 2 and 3 to ensure their employees and anyone else who could be affected by their work (such as visitors, members of the public, patients, contractors etc), are kept safe from harm and that their health is not affected. This means slips and trips risks must be controlled, the trust complies with this by –
Task based risk assessments that highlight any slips, trips issues
Visual inspections of shared areas , i.e. corridors, ground and public areas to mitigate risks to individuals falling.
Staff induction training which includes slips, trips awareness.
Undertaking training e-learning or face to face for slips, trips awareness
As appropriate providing relevant staff PPE in the form of footwear and ensuring appropriate footwear is worn as per u8niform policy.
Reporting or undertaking safe actions to mitigate and proactively manage slip, trip fall risks.
As far as reasonably practicable ,ensuring good lighting and sound flooring
Maintenance of flooring and lighting both proactive and reactive via the EFM helpdesk.
Safe Plant and Equipment

All equipment within the Trust will be identified for specific purpose following an assessment process. This will include the maintenance and purchase arrangements in place in line with current Legislation and HSE Publication – The Provision and Use of Work Equipment Regulations. If equipment is faulty, staff must report it to their line manager; generally non-medical equipment will be maintained through the local EFM help desk. For medical equipment refer to the Medical Devices Policy.
Vehicles and Ride on Equipment

Any vehicle or 'ride on' item of equipment which is used to transport material, or waste will undergo a planned preventative maintenance programme (on at least an annual basis). Pre-shift maintenance checks will be carried out on each vehicle. Defects highlighted during such checks will cease the operation of that vehicle immediately.
Staff using such equipment will receive training in its use in order that it may be used safely. Staff may only use such equipment if they have been trained in its use.
Staff using Trust vehicles or equipment are not permitted to make any alterations or adaptations.
